WINTERING MATURE BROOD SOWS llv \\ I*. Snydkn IMIK ll«»\ During iiovcn winter* twenty or more brood now* that had produced at leant one litter were kept during a connldernble Eart of th« winter on ration* eonnlntlng of corn and alfalfa ay or alfalfa hay alone, The alfalfa wan fed In proportions varying from the relatively nmnll amount taken from >t tack by mown being fed nome corn, to a ration conalntlng entirely of alfalfa. The alfalfa wan fed In the form of alfalfa hay or chopped alfalfa, and of chopped alfalfa ntewed or boiled In water. During the punt winter we have uned h machine that mi i the alfalfa no tine that It mlxen readily with ground com and yet In not a dimly meal. A nummary of the renultn of dun yearn' tentn In which one lot of nown wan fed alfalfa In n ruck nnil another lot whn fi<d chopped alfalfa and chopped corn In equal proportion*, lioth lotn getting about equal amouuln or grain, In minted below from Mulletfn 147, Popular Kiliiion. Thene renultn were rather favorable to feeding a light grain ration of about one pound of grain dally per loo poundn weight, with alfalfa hay In a rack, Later exiierlmeiitn, the renultn of which are glvwn In thin bulletin, Indicate that old brood nown may be wintered on alfalfa alone with fair lUWWW altho thin mm not be a profit - able practice under unual condltlonn, Thene renultn alno Hull cnt" that the clieapMnl cut Ion, when credit In given for the vain made, In a light ration of corn and alfalfa nay In a rack. I'll" mont recent lent Indicates Hud old brood nowM may he wintered nallnfartorlly lining nelf-feedem mimI a radon of thru poundn of chopped iiliiilhi to one pound of <'hopped corn, We have lined lit compiling thene renultn the prlcen that prevailed when Ihe flint experiment herein reported wan be- Kin. 14 Nebraska Agricultural Exp. Station, Bulletin 162 in a rack was $3.19 with a gain of 22 pounds. If we should weigh the sows into and out of the test, allowing $6.50 per 100 pounds as the value, the net cost of keeping a sow ten weeks would range from $1.83 for hogs fed shelled corn and alfalfa hay to $3.92 for the sows fed chopped alfalfa and silage. Nebraska Agricultural Exp. Station, Bulletin 162 16 FEKD1NU OLD UKOOD SOWS ON ALFALFA ALONE OR ON ALFALFA AND (JKAIN Second Test The test made during the winter of 1914-1915 was re - peated during the winter of 1915-1916 with changes in the rations of certain lots. The ration of alfalfa hay and silage and the ration of stewed alfalfa and less than 0.5 per cent corn were not repeated. The other four rations were repeated. The rations of alfalfa hay and 1 per cent com and of alfalfa hay alone were duplicated with two lots having access to self - waterers that furnished tepid water at all times. The sows were of the same character and kept under the same condi - tions as during the previous winter. The prices used in cal - culating the results are the same as used for the previous winter. RATIONS Lot A Alfalfa hay in rack, stewed alfalfa and 1.05 per cent ground corn. Lot C Alfalfa hay in rack and stewed alfalfa. Lot D Alfalfa hay in rack and 1.25 per cent corn. Lot E Alfalfa hay in rack. Lot G Alfalfa hay in rack and self-waterer. Lot H Alfalfa hay in rack, 1.25 per cent corn, self- waterer. Alfalfa hay was kept in racks for all the hogs at all times. The sows in Lot A were fed daily 1.05 pounds of ground corn per 100 pounds of their weight. The corn was mixed with all the stewed alfalfa the sows would eat. They ate daily 0.7L pound per 100 pounds of their weight of stewed alfalfa and from the rack daily they ate 0.82 pound per 100 pounds of their weight of alfalfa hay. This ration was a very close duplication of the ration fed to Lot A during the winter of 19 J 4-1915. The sows in Lot C were fed the same ration as the sows in Lot G of the previous winter. This was all the stewed alfalfa they would eat with alfalfa hay in the rack. Of the stewed alfalfa they ate 0.45 pound and of the alfalfa hay 1 pound per 100 pounds of their weight daily. These sows ate 4.5 pounds alfalfa per head daily. The sows in Lot D were fed practically the same ration as those in Lot D the previous winter except that ear corn was fed during the second winter in place of shelled corn.

Wintering Mature Brood Sows 17 These sows ate 1.26 pounds of corn (shelled) and 0.85 pound alfalfa hay daily per 100 pounds of their weight. They ate 3.12 pounds corn and 3 pounds alfalfa per head daily. It re - quired 3.9 bushels of corn and 200 pounds alfalfa to keep a 300-pound sow 10 weeks and increase her weight 44.4 pounds. In Lot E the sows were fed alfalfa hay alone as were the sows in Lot E during the previous winter. Each sow ate 5.6 pounds alfalfa hay daily on an average, or 1.79 pounds daily per 100 pounds weight. The sows in Lot G were fed in the same manner as those in Lot E, but instead of being watered twice daily at a trough they were supplied with a water tank where a lamp kept the temperature of the water above the freezing point during the coldest weather and tepid during most of the time. These sows ate practically the same amount of alfalfa hay as those in Lot E. The sows in Lot H were fed the same ration as those in Lot D, but were supplied with water in the same manner as the sows in Lot G. These sows were fed practically the same amount of corn as the sows in Lot D and ate about the same amount of alfalfa from the rack. WEIGHT The average initial weight of the 30 sows was 311 pounds ; the smallest sow weighed 252 pounds, and the largest 422 pounds. At the end of the 10 weeks the average weight was 334 pounds per sow; the smallest sow weighed 260 pounds, and the largest 442 pounds. The sows in Lot A, fed daily 1.05 pounds corn, 0.79 pound stewed alfalfa, and 0.82 pound alfalfa hay per 100 pounds weight, made quite a uniform gain of 72.3 pounds each at the rate of over 1 pound per head daily. In Lot C where the daily ration was 0.45 pound stewed alfalfa and 1 pound of hay per 100 pounds weight, four sows lost 12 pounds each on the average, and one sow gained 5 pounds. Stewed alfalfa and alfalfa hay in a rack did not constitute a maintenance ration in this test. The sows in Lot D, fed 1.26 pounds corn and 0.86 pound alfalfa hay daily per 100 pounds weight, made a fairly uni - form gain of 44.4 pounds each, at the rate of 0.63 pound per head daily.

20 Nebraska Agricultural Exp. Station, Bulletin 162 In Lot E, where the sows were fed only alfalfa hay in a rack, three sows gained on the average 8.5 pounds each, one sow maintained her initial weight, and one sow lost 7.5 pounds. The net gain was 18 pounds or 8.6 pounds per sow. In this test 1.79 pounds alfalfa hay per 100 pounds weight, taken from the rack daily by the sow, maintained her weight for 70 days and allowed a slight gain. Or 5.6 pounds alfalfa hay daily, waste included, maintained a sow weighing 814 pounds. The ration of the sows in Lot G duplicates that of the sows in Lot E, but the sows in Lot G had access to water at all times. This did not give evidence of being of any special bene - fit in this test as the sows in Lot G lost 6.2 pounds each in weight during the test. Alfalfa hay alone was not a main - tenance ration. The sows ate daily from the rack 1.84 pounds alfalfa hay per 100 pounds weight, or 5.7 pounds per head daily, waste included. Lot H duplicated Lot D except that the sows in Lot H had access to water at all times. The sows ate 1.25 pounds corn and 0.98 pound alfalfa hay daily per 100 pounds of their weight, and made an average gain of 89 pounds per head. The sows in Lot D ate practically the same amount of feed but gained a few pounds more. There is nothing in these results to indicate that the self-waterer gave any better results than watering twice daily in a trough. The effect of the ra - tions as shown in the weight of the sows is summed up in table 7. Wintering Mature Brood Sows 21 EKKECT OK RATIONS ON UTTERS The farrowing record of 27 of the 80 sows is given in detail in table 8. The size of the pigs, number farrowed and number raised are about the same as the average of the pre - ceding five years. The average number of pigs farrowed per litter was 10, number of live pigs 8.1, and of dead pigs 1.9. Tho average pig weighed 2.36 pounds at birth, and 50 pounds when 92 days old. At this time there was an average of 6.8 pigs per litter farrowed. There is no definite indication that the ration fed during the ten weeks had any marked effect on the litter except that the pigs from sows that had lost weight were smaller when farrowed than the pigs from sows that had gained in weight. However, more pigs were raised per litter from the sows that lost weight than from those that gained most in weight. Five sows that had been fed stewed alfalfa only and had lost a total of 48 pounds in weight during the ten weeks of the test, farrowed 50 live pigs and raised 86. The average weight at birth of the pigs from these sows was 2.09 pounds. Four sows that had been fed alfalfa hay in a rack and no grain during the ten weeks farrowed 81 live pigs and raised 22, or 5.6 each. Those pigs weighed 2.1 pounds each at birth. A group of three sows that had no grain during the ten weeks farrowed 24 live pigs out of a total of 29, weighing 2.88 pounds each at birth. These three sows raised 22 pigs. The largest gain made by a group of sows during the ten weeks was 361.5 pounds by the sows in Lot A, fed 1,06 per cent corn and stewed alfalfa. These sows farrowed 8.2 five pigs each. The average weight of all the pigs farrowed by these sows was 2.46 pounds. These sows raised 6 pin per litter. The next largest gain was made by the hows In Lot D, fed 1.25 per cent corn and alfalfa hay in a rack. These sows gained 222 pounds, and farrowed 9.2 live pigs per Utter, or • total of 11.4 piss per litter, having an average weight of 2.19 pounds. They raised 7.2 pigi per litter. The jows that ranked third in gain made during the ten weeks were fed 1.26 per cent corn and alfalfa hay in a rack and were self' watered. This group gave the poorest results in number far - rowed and number raited. They farrowed 6.8 live pigs per litter, or a total of 8.2 pigs per litter, weighing 2.89 pounds per pig. They raised 6.2 plgi per litter. These result* tend to show that a mature sow may be wintered on a maintenance ration without great if any injury to the litter she is carrying.
